If you‚Äôre not an experienced maker I wouldn‚Äôt start with VX21. If you make a mistake once it‚Äôs been sewn and need to unpick it the panel is essentially useless because it‚Äôs full of holes, I would stick to cordura since it‚Äôs cheap and easy to work. I‚Äôve actually got a couple of videos on making frame bags, one for the template which is here https://youtu.be/FfbFNhRaaGg and the bag itself here https://youtu.be/QZbyCHCqjdQ. As others have mentioned ripstopbytheroll or rockywoods are the best places for fabric in the US, if you‚Äôre in the UK it‚Äôs Profabrics and the EU somewhere like extremtextil. Personally I don‚Äôt seam seal any of my bags, I just edge the insides with nylon binding material but seal sealing is a possibility. The problem is with a bag that‚Äôs stitched together is that you‚Äôre always going to have potential for water ingress. I tell all my customers to use dry bags in their bags if they have sensitive equipment because no matter how hard you try, water will get in. data.text: I made my own top tube bag for a recent bikepacking trip to Big Bend. I used ripstop by the roll and rocky roads. I bought lots of cordura, a yard or two of a few different types, just to get a feel for it. I made a cardboard template, then sewed a few panels to figure out if my ideas were going to work, then eventually made two bags that were finished to varying degrees. My third try was the bag I used on the trip, and it served its purpose well, very happy with it. Take your time, sew individual panels, work with different stitch spacing, materials, etc. Practice, a lot. Good luck!!
